title: Occultism: Exploring Hidden Knowledge
description: An exploration of occult philosophies, practices, and traditions, focusing on esoteric knowledge and hidden aspects of reality.

paragraphs.summary: An introduction to Occultism as the study of hidden or secret wisdom, often involving paranormal phenomena, magic, and esoteric spiritual paths.
Knowledge intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with specialized knowledge or interest; often contrasted with exoteric (public) teachings.
A philosophical and religious tradition based on writings attributed to Hermes Trismegistus, influential in Western esotericism, alchemy, and magic.
A core Hermetic principle asserting a correspondence between the macrocosm (universe) and the microcosm (human being/Earth).
Ancient religious and philosophical movements emphasizing personal spiritual knowledge (gnosis) over faith or dogma for salvation.
An esoteric method, discipline, and school of thought in Jewish mysticism, often adapted in Western occult traditions (Hermetic Qabalah).
A central diagram in Kabbalah representing the ten Sephirot or divine emanations and the paths connecting them, mapping creation and consciousness.
The occult practice aiming for spiritual transformation (inner gold) and often, allegorically or literally, the transmutation of base metals into gold.
The study of the movements and relative positions of celestial bodies interpreted as having an influence on human affairs and the natural world.
The attempt to gain insight into a question or situation by way of an occultic, standardized process or ritual (e.g., Tarot, I Ching, scrying).
A pack of playing cards, used from the mid-15th century in various parts of Europe to play games, and since the late 18th century for divination and esoteric purposes.
The belief in a mystical or divine relationship between a number and one or more coinciding events or characteristics.
The art and science of causing change to occur in conformity with Will (Crowley's definition), often involving ritual, symbolism, and altered states.
Magic involving elaborate rituals, tools, and often the invocation of spirits or deities, common in Western esoteric traditions.
Symbols created for a specific magical purpose, often representing a desired outcome or a spiritual entity, charged with will.
Invocation is calling a spiritual entity 'into' oneself or a space. Evocation is calling a spiritual entity 'forth' into external appearance or manifestation.
An interpretation of an out-of-body experience (OBE) assuming the existence of an 'astral body' separate from the physical body, capable of traveling.
The practice of looking into a suitable medium (e.g., crystal ball, mirror, water) in the hope of detecting significant messages or visions.
Amulets are objects believed to offer protection from harm or evil. Talismans are objects believed to possess magical properties to bring good luck or specific powers to the wearer.
An esoteric philosophical and religious movement established by Helena Blavatsky, drawing on Eastern and Western mystical traditions, seeking universal divine wisdom.
A spiritual philosophy founded by Rudolf Steiner, postulating an objective, intellectually comprehensible spiritual world accessible to direct experience through inner development.
A philosophical secret society said to have been founded in late medieval Germany by Christian Rosenkreuz, holding a doctrine built on esoteric truths of the ancient past.
The esoteric interpretations and practices within Freemasonry, focusing on symbolic allegory, moral instruction, and spiritual development through ritual.
The Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, a late 19th/early 20th-century magical order that was highly influential on Western occultism.
A spiritual philosophy and new religious movement developed by Aleister Crowley, centered on the principle 'Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law'.
Modern Pagan religions, often nature-based, including Wicca (a modern witchcraft tradition), Druidry, and Heathenry, emphasizing reverence for nature and often polytheistic.
A contemporary magical practice emphasizing pragmatic use of belief systems and a rejection of fixed dogma, often utilizing sigils and altered states.
A term for spiritual paths that emphasize self-deification, individualism, and often challenge conventional morality, contrasted with the Right-Hand Path (focus on union with Divine/Source).
A term for spiritual paths that emphasize union with a divine source, adherence to established moral codes, and often involve devotion and service.
The idea in many esoteric systems that reality consists of multiple, interpenetrating dimensions or planes of existence (e.g., physical, astral, mental, spiritual).
Belief in subtle energy fields (auras) surrounding living beings, and vital life forces (like Prana or Chi) that can be manipulated or cultivated.
In Hindu and Tantric traditions, energy centers or plexuses within the subtle body, often aligned along the spine, associated with various physiological and psychic functions.
In Hindu Tantrism, a primal spiritual energy or life force envisioned as a coiled serpent at the base of the spine, which can be awakened through yogic practices.
Meditative practices in occult traditions often focus on visualization, achieving altered states of consciousness, and interacting with symbolic or spiritual realms.
Principles and methods for designing and performing effective magical or spiritual rituals, including symbolism, timing, tools, and intent.
Textbooks of magic, typically including instructions on how to create magical objects, perform spells, summon spirits, and cast divinations.
Organizations that conceal their rituals, membership, or teachings from outsiders, often associated with esoteric knowledge and initiatory systems.
A rite of passage marking entrance or acceptance into a group or society, or a new level of spiritual attainment, often involving symbolic death and rebirth.
A belief system postulating that the spirits of the dead can and do communicate with the living, typically through a medium.
The study of alleged psychic phenomena (extrasensory perception, telekinesis) and other paranormal claims, often on the fringes of mainstream science.
A broad movement characterized by alternative approaches to spirituality, mysticism, and self-help, often drawing eclectically from various traditions.
The study and interpretation of complex symbols used in various occult traditions to represent esoteric concepts, cosmic forces, and psychological states.
Systems (e.g., in astrology, Kabbalah, magic) that link various elements like planets, metals, herbs, colors, numbers, and deities based on perceived symbolic or energetic affinities.

A term used in theosophy (and other esoteric philosophies) for a compendium of all universal events, thoughts, words, emotions, and intent ever to have occurred in the past, present, or future in terms of all entities and life forms, not just human.
Thoughtforms are psychic manifestations created by focused thought or will. Egregores are autonomous psychic entities created by and influencing a collective group mind.
A dream during which the dreamer is aware that they are dreaming and may be able to exert some degree of control over the dream narrative or environment.
A technique of guided visualization or meditation used in some Western esoteric traditions to explore symbolic landscapes (e.g., paths on the Kabbalistic Tree of Life).
Practices aimed at perceiving, manipulating, or balancing supposed subtle energies or life forces (e.g., chi, prana, odic force) for magical or healing purposes.
Exploration of various tools beyond Tarot used for divination, such as runes, the I Ching (Book of Changes), pendulums, and geomancy.
The ethical considerations and moral frameworks within various occult traditions, addressing issues like responsibility, intent, and the use of power.
The critical examination of occult claims and phenomena from scientific, rationalist, or skeptical perspectives, including common debunking arguments.
The intersection of occult practices and concepts with psychological theories, particularly Jungian archetypes, the collective unconscious, and transpersonal psychology.
The resurgence and evolution of interest in occult and esoteric subjects in contemporary society, often facilitated by the internet and new media.
